name: Reformation and Jihad Front
description: In early 2007, the Mujahideen Army (MA), the Islamic Army in Iraq (IAI), Ansar al-Islam (AI) and Ansar al-Sunna Sharia (AS Sharia) formed the Jihad and Reform Front (RJF) to oppose AQI's Islamic State of Iraq in response to ISI's targeting of civilians and members of MA, IAI AI, and AS Sharia.

name: Mujahideen Shura Council
description: In January 2006, Al Qaeda in Iraq (AQI) joined with five other groups to form the Mujahideen Shura Council (MSC) in order to better coordinate attacks against U.S. Coalition forces and to improve AQI's image in Iraq by officially partnering with Iraqi groups.

name: Palestinian Liberation Organization
description: The Palestinian Liberation Organization (PLO) seeks the creation of a Palestinian state, initially following Abdul Nasser's ""pan-Arab"" ideology. The PLO has enjoyed observer status in the United Nations since 1974, and is seen by both the Arab League and United Nations as the sole legitimate representative of the Palestinian people. It was considered a terrorist entity by the United States until the 1991 Madrid Conference. The leader of the PLO, until 2004, was Yasser Arafat. He was succeeded by Mahmoud Abbas. There is a strong connection between the PLO and Hamas, both politically and ideologically.

name: The Political Council for the Iraqi Resistance
description: In November 2007, Hamas in Iraq, along with parts of the Islamic Army in Iraq (IAI), the Mujahideen Army, Ansar al-Sunna Shariah, the Fatiheen Army, and the Islamic Front for the Iraqi Resistance, formed the Political Council for the Iraqi Resistance (IRPC) in opposition to AQI's Islamic State of Iraq (ISI).

name: Al Qaeda
description: Al Qaeda is the largest and most extensive Islamic militant organization in the world. Founded by Osama bin Laden as a part of the anti-Soviet mujahideen of the 1980s, al Qaeda seeks the liberation of the Muslim world from foreign influence, and has carried out attacks against thousands of targets throughout the Middle East, Asia, Europe, North America, and Africa. Al Qaeda has provided support or allied with dozens of organizations over the past quarter-century, most notably the Taliban, Haqqani Network, and Abu Sayyaf. Through this support and training of militants, al Qaeda has emerged as one of the most violent militant organizations in the world.

name: Islamic State of Iraq
description: The Islamic State of Iraq is an umbrella group for a number of Iraqi insurgency groups. The organization is comprised of a number of militant organizations, though the majority of these are independent from al Qaeda. Most notably, al Qaeda in Iraq (AQI) aligned with the ISI following its creation, separating itself from the Mujahideen Shura Council.

name: Simon Bolivar Guerrilla Coordinating Board
description: The Simon Bolivar Guerrilla Coordinating Group was created in 1987 by leftist revolutionary groups in Colombia in order to coordinate attacks and government negotiations. However, as the leftist groups began to diverge tactically and ideologically, the need for a coordinating board weakened. The CGSV disbanded in the early 1990's; however, many of the organizations it hosted are still active today.

name: United Jihad Council
description: Established in the summer of 1994, the UJC/MJC aims to fight Indian rule in Kashmir. Several of the members are considered terrorist organizations by the United States and/or the United Nations The group seeks to unify and strengthen the fighters against the Indian control of Kashmir, making the distribution of resources, such as finances and weapons, more streamlined. Among unlisted members are:  Harakat-ul-Ansar, Jamiat-ul-Mujahideen, Al-Jihad, Al-Barq, Al-Badr, Ikhwan-ul-Mussalmin, Tehrik-ul-Mujahideen, and Tehrik-e-Jihad.

name: Islamic Front
description: The Islamic Front was an umbrella organization formed by seven groups (Ahrar al-Sham, Suquor al-Sham, the Tawhid Brigade of Aleppo, Jaysh al-Islam, Liwa al-Haqq, the Kurdish Islamic Front (KIF), and Ansar al-Sham) in November 2013 to overthrow the Assad Regime and establish an Islamic government. At its peak, the organization had 40,000 to 70,000 fighters, and represented the largest alliance of opposition forces that has existed in the Syrian conflict. However, the organization’s constituent groups drifted apart in mid-2014 due to disagreements between the Islamic Front’s most powerful members: Ahrar al-Sham and Jaysh al-Islam. The umbrella group is now defunct, although Liwa al-Tawhid and other former Islamic Front battalions briefly referred to themselves as an independent group known as the Islamic Front before forming the Levantine Front in the Aleppo governorate.

name: Syrian Islamic Front
description: Ahrar al-Sham formed the Syrian Islamic Front (SIF) umbrella group in December 2012 in order to unite Syrian Islamist opposition forces and pursue a government that implements Shariah law. The SIF did not  come under the command of the Free Syrian Army’s Supreme Military Council (SMC), but it regularly coordinated military maneuvers with SMC affiliated brigades. In January 2013, Ahrar al-Sham absorbed three smaller SIF groups (Harakat al-Fajr al-Islamiya, Jamaat al-Taliaa al-Islamiya, and Kataeb al-Iman al-Muqatila) and became the SIF’s largest member. Ahrar al-Sham dissolved the SIF in November 2013 in order to form the Islamic Front.

name: Syrian Islamic Liberation Front
description: The Syrian Islamic Liberation Front (SILF) was an umbrella organization of several Free Syrian Army (FSA) affiliated groups, including Suqour al-Sham and Liwa al-Tawhid, that opposed the Assad Regime. Suqour al-Sham led the SILF’s formation, and Suqour al-Sham leader Abu Eissa became the head of the SILF. The group dissolved in late 2013 after Suqour al-Sham, Liwa al-Tawhid, and Jaysh al-Islam left to join the Islamic Front umbrella organization.

name: Popular Mobilization Forces
description: The Popular Mobilization Forces is a state-sponsored organization composed of roughly forty Shiite militias that was formed by the Iraqi Government on June 15, 2014 in order to work alongside the Iraqi Armed Forces fighting the Islamic State (IS). The organization appears to be led by the commanders of three of its largest member groups: Qais al-Khazali of Asa'ib Ahl al-Haq, Abu Mahdi al-Muhandis of Kata'ib Hezbollah, and Hadi al-Amiri of the Badr Organization. The Popular Mobilization Units were heavily involved in the Iraqi Army's offensive to retake Tikrit from IS in March 2015 and have subsequently been active in the Anbar province. However, the Iraq government has announced that the organization will not participate in the anticipated battle to retake Mosul from IS; many sources attribute this decision the sectarian killings of Sunni Iraqis purportedly perpetrated by members of the Popular Mobilization Forces during its previous campaigns in majority Sunni areas. While this umbrella organization has been active in Iraq, there have been no confirmed operations by this group in Syria.

name: The Coordination of the Movements of Azawad
description: The Coordination of the Movements of Azawad (CMA) is a separatist movement created in November 2013 by the National Movement for the Liberation of Azawad (MNLA), the Arab Movement of Azawad (MAA), and High Council for the Unity of Azawad (HCUA).  The group formed with the intention of negotiating with international governments in order to gain recogniztion for the state of Azawad in northern Mali as a separate political and legal entity.  On June 10, 2014 the CMA agreed to open talks with the Algerian government to discuss reconciliation.  On June 20, 2015, the CMA signed the Agreement on Peace and Reconciliation in Mali, with the Malian government, which would establish political and institutional reforms related to defense and security.

name: Syrian Democratic Forces
description: The Syrian Democratic Forces (SDF) is an umbrella organization of Arab and Kurdish forces that oppose the Islamic State (IS) in Northern and Eastern Syria. The SDF was established in October 2015, and the Kurdish People’s Protection Units (YPG) is the most prominent group within the umbrella organization. The SDF receives weapons and military assistance from the United States, and is currently fighting to recapture the city of Manbij from IS.

name: Jaysh al-Fatah
description: Jaysh al-Fatah (Army of Conquest) is an umbrella organization that was formed on March 24, 2015, and includes Jabhat Fatah al-Sham (Fatah al-Sham), formerly known as Jabhat al-Nusra, Ahrar al-Sham, and several smaller brigades such as Ferliq al-Sham, Ajnad al-Sham, Jaysh al-Sunnah, al-Haq Brigade, and Jund al-Aqsa. The umbrella organization rose to prominence after it took control of the Idlib governorate from the Assad Regime in March 2015, and quickly spread throughout Syria. Following its Idlib offensive, Jaysh al-Fatah began receiving funding from Saudi Arabia and Turkey. Recently, Jaysh al-Fatah helped break the Syrian army’s siege on opposition-held areas in the city of Aleppo.
